G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action under G.L. c. 218, § 19 because the amount in controversy is within the District Court’s jurisdictional limit.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and G.L. c. 223, § 2, as the cause of action arose in this judicial district.

Newton Revised Ordinances, Ch. 3, \u00a7.proposition: The City of Newton’s leash law, Newton Revised Ordinances, Ch. 3, § 3-52, creates a statutory standard of care, and violation thereof is evidence of negligence. See Breen v. Burns, 280 Mass. 222, 226 (1932); G.L. c. 140, §§ 155–158.

Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every person has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm to others. See Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states, as a general principle of Massachusetts tort law, that every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others, conditioned on foreseeability of the risk. This directly matches the cited proposition about a general duty of reasonable care to avoid foreseeable harm, and the court relies on this principle in its duty analysis.
Jupin v. Kask, 447 Mass. 141, 146 (2006).relevant_excerpt: "We have recognized that ‘[a]s a general principle of tort law, every actor has a duty to exercise reasonable care to avoid physical harm to others.’ See Remy v. MacDonald, supra at 677, citing Restatement (Second) Torts § 302 comment a (1965). A precondition to this duty is, of course, that the risk of harm to another be recognizable or foreseeable to the actor."

Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 1.raw_text: Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 158, 161 (1933)
Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 1.proposition: Defendant owed a duty to Plaintiff to control his dog and keep it on a leash, consistent with both common law duties of reasonable care and municipal ordinances. See Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 158, 161 (1933); Whalen v. Shivek, 326 Mass. 142, 149 (1950).
Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 1.support_reasoning: The case rejects liability and expressly states that, absent statute or ordinance requiring leashing, there was no duty based on common law to restrain an ordinarily harmless dog. The court notes there was no Boston order or ordinance requiring dogs to be leashed and explicitly declines to consider the effect of such a law. Thus, Andrews does not stand for a duty to control and leash a dog under common law and ordinances; it instead holds that no such duty existed on these facts.
Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 1.relevant_excerpt: "There was no evidence, and it was not matter of common knowledge, that the presence in the store of a dog having no dangerous propensities was a probable source of harm to customers... And this is true though such dog was not restrained. No statute... and no order or ordinance, so far as the evidence shows, requires dogs in Boston to be kept on leash or otherwise restrained... and we need not consider the effect of such a statute, order or ordinance."

Whalen v. Shivek, 326 Mass. 142, 149 (19.proposition: Defendant owed a duty to Plaintiff to control his dog and keep it on a leash, consistent with both common law duties of reasonable care and municipal ordinances. See Andrews v. Jordan Marsh Co., 283 Mass. 158, 161 (1933); Whalen v. Shivek, 326 Mass. 142, 149 (1950).
Whalen v. Shivek, 326 Mass. 142, 149 (19.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns liability of a building owner, tenant, and construction contractor for a collapsing parapet; it does not involve dogs, animals, leashes, or any analogous duty to control an animal. The duties discussed are about safely performing construction work adjacent to a public sidewalk and landlord/tenant nuisance principles. Accordingly, Whalen v. Shivek does not provide authority for a proposition about a defendant’s duty to control his dog or comply with leash ordinances.
Whalen v. Shivek, 326 Mass. 142, 149 (19.relevant_excerpt: "In carrying on its work on that part of the building which was immediately adjacent to the sidewalk the contractor was under a duty to perform it in a manner that would not create an unreasonable risk of harm to members of the public who might use the sidewalk. The evidence, in our opinion, warranted a finding that this duty was violated."

Foley v. F. W. Woolworth Co., 293 Mass..raw_text: Foley v. F. W. Woolworth Co., 293 Mass. 232 (1936)
Foley v. F. W. Woolworth Co., 293 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that an owner’s failure to restrain an animal constitutes actionable negligence where injury results. See Foley v. F. W. Woolworth Co., 293 Mass. 232 (1936); Maillet v. Mininno, 266 Mass. 86 (1929).
Foley v. F. W. Woolworth Co., 293 Mass..case_name: Foley v. F. W. Woolworth Co.
Foley v. F. W. Woolworth Co., 293 Mass..support_reasoning: The case concerns premises liability for a slip-and-fall on a foreign substance (vomit) on a store stairway, focusing on whether the store had constructive notice of the hazard and failed to remove it. It does not involve animals, animal restraint, or duties related to keeping animals, and thus provides no authority for the proposition about an owner’s failure to restrain an animal constituting actionable negligence.
Foley v. F. W. Woolworth Co., 293 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “This is an action of tort… while she was walking down a stairway… she slipped on a large area of foreign, slippery and slimy substance which the defendant permitted to be on a portion of said stairway, which condition it could have remedied by the exercise of reasonable diligence… from its character, its consistency, dryness, hardness and general appearance the jury were warranted in drawing an inference… that it had been on the stairway long enough to have been known of and removed before the accident.”

Maillet v. Mininno, 266 Mass. 86 (1929).proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that an owner’s failure to restrain an animal constitutes actionable negligence where injury results. See Foley v. F. W. Woolworth Co., 293 Mass. 232 (1936); Maillet v. Mininno, 266 Mass. 86 (1929).
Maillet v. Mininno, 266 Mass. 86 (1929).support_reasoning: The case is decided under G.L. c. 140, § 155, which imposes statutory liability on the owner or keeper of a dog; it does not analyze common‑law negligence, duty to restrain animals, or failure to restrain as a basis of liability. The opinion focuses solely on whether the defendants were properly alleged and proved to be joint owners/keepers under the statute. It therefore does not provide authority for the proposition that an owner’s failure to restrain an animal constitutes actionable negligence in Massachusetts.
Maillet v. Mininno, 266 Mass. 86 (1929).relevant_excerpt: "G. L. c. 140, § 155, provides: ‘The owner or keeper of a dog shall be liable in tort to a person injured by it in double the amount of damages sustained by him.’ She brought action, thereunder, against Agostino Mininno and his wife Rachele… Here if Agostino and Rachele jointly were both owners and keepers of the dog, a liability would be established. There was an issue of fact for the jury."

Breen v. Burns, 280 Mass. 222, 226 (1932.proposition: The City of Newton’s leash law, Newton Revised Ordinances, Ch. 3, § 3-52, creates a statutory standard of care, and violation thereof is evidence of negligence. See Breen v. Burns, 280 Mass. 222, 226 (1932); G.L. c. 140, §§ 155–158.
Breen v. Burns, 280 Mass. 222, 226 (1932.support_reasoning: The opinion in Breen v. Burns concerns statutes of limitations for claims against an estate for funeral expenses and contains no discussion of dog leash laws, municipal ordinances, or statutory standards of care in negligence. It neither cites G.L. c. 140, §§ 155–158 nor addresses whether violation of a leash law constitutes evidence of negligence. Thus, this case does not provide authority for the claimed proposition about Newton’s leash law creating a statutory standard of care.
Breen v. Burns, 280 Mass. 222, 226 (1932.relevant_excerpt: There is no discussion anywhere in the opinion of G.L. c. 140, §§ 155–158, of any leash law, or of statutory standards of care or negligence per se; the case is confined to issues of funeral expenses, estate liability, and statutes of limitations under G.L. c. 197 and c. 260.

G.L. c. 140, \u00a7\u00a7 155\u2013158.proposition: The City of Newton’s leash law, Newton Revised Ordinances, Ch. 3, § 3-52, creates a statutory standard of care, and violation thereof is evidence of negligence. See Breen v. Burns, 280 Mass. 222, 226 (1932); G.L. c. 140, §§ 155–158.

Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.raw_text: Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978)
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.proposition: Defendant’s conduct was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries. Proximate cause exists where the harm is a reasonably foreseeable result of the defendant’s act. See Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 376 Mass. 101, 105 (1978).
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.support_reasoning: The opinion directly addresses proximate cause and adopts a foreseeability-based formulation: an intervening third-party act does not break causation if it ought to have been foreseen. The court explains that the original negligence remains a “culpable and direct cause” where the probable injurious consequences were to be anticipated, and then applies that rule to hold that the plaintiff’s injury could be found to have been caused by the defendant’s negligence. This aligns with the proposition that proximate cause exists when the harm is a reasonably foreseeable result of the defendant’s act.
Jesionek v. Massachusetts Port Auth., 37.relevant_excerpt: “The general rule is that ‘[t]he act of a third person, intervening and contributing a condition necessary to the injurious effect of the original negligence, will not excuse the first wrongdoer, if such act ought to have been foreseen. The original negligence still remains a culpable and direct cause of the injury. The test is to be found in the probable injurious consequences which were to be anticipated, not in the number of subsequent events and agencies which might arise.’ … Under the facts of this case the jury would have been warranted in concluding that the actions of the seaman were foreseeable… Consequently, a jury could have found that the plaintiff’s injury was caused by a negligent act for which the authority was responsible.”

Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.raw_text: Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co., 388 Mass. 342, 355 (1983)
Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.proposition: Plaintiff’s response—swerving to avoid the charging dog—was a natural reaction to Defendant’s negligence and does not constitute comparative fault. See Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co., 388 Mass. 342, 355 (1983).
Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.case_name: Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.
Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.support_reasoning: The opinion is a products liability/workers’ compensation allocation case and does not involve any facts about a plaintiff swerving to avoid a dog or any similar emergency reaction scenario. Its discussion of comparative negligence appears only in the context of whether comparative negligence applies to breach of warranty and how an employee’s or employer’s negligence is treated in that framework. It does not address whether a plaintiff’s instinctive evasive maneuver in response to a defendant-created danger is non‑fault or excused from comparative negligence analysis, so it does not support the cited proposition.
Correia v. Firestone Tire & Rubber Co.,.relevant_excerpt: “No recovery by the plaintiff shall be diminished on account of any other conduct which might be deemed contributorily negligent.” (388 Mass. at 357).

McCusker v. Spier, 72 Mass. App. Ct. 110.raw_text: McCusker v. Spier, 72 Mass. App. Ct. 1101 (2008) (Rule 1:28 decision)
McCusker v. Spier, 72 Mass. App. Ct. 110.proposition: Even though the dog did not physically contact Plaintiff, Defendant’s negligence in failing to restrain his dog foreseeably caused Plaintiff to suffer injury. See McCusker v. Spier, 72 Mass. App. Ct. 1101 (2008) (Rule 1:28 decision) (owner liable where victim’s evasive response to dog’s behavior caused injury).

Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.proposition: Defendant’s negligence violated established Massachusetts principles of reasonable care, including those articulated in Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973), Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84, 88 (1988), and Jenkins v. Rainear, 371 Mass. 293 (1976).
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard abolished the rigid common‑law distinctions between licensees and invitees in Massachusetts and replaced them with a general duty of reasonable care owed by occupiers, which is the type of “established Massachusetts principle of reasonable care” the proposition invokes. The provided text is from a concurrence criticizing the continued special treatment of trespassers, but it still operates within and comments on the majority’s adoption of a broader reasonable‑care standard. Although this excerpt does not restate the holding, the case as a whole is correctly cited as foundational authority for Massachusetts’ modern reasonable‑care standard toward entrants on land.
Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1.relevant_excerpt: The court holds that the measure of responsibility of an occupier should no longer depend on whether the injured person is characterized as a “licensee” rather than an “invitee,” or vice versa; the question is to turn on other, more vital factors.

Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84, 88 (.proposition: Defendant’s negligence violated established Massachusetts principles of reasonable care, including those articulated in Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973), Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84, 88 (1988), and Jenkins v. Rainear, 371 Mass. 293 (1976).
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84, 88 (.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly articulates and applies the Massachusetts reasonable-care standard for landowners drawn from Mounsey and related cases, stating that the defendant had a duty to maintain the property in a reasonably safe condition considering likelihood and seriousness of harm and burden of precautions. Although the court ultimately finds no negligence on these facts, it affirms the governing principles of reasonable care in premises liability that the proposition references. Thus, it is properly cited as authority for the applicable standard of care, even if not for a finding of breach here.
Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84, 88 (.relevant_excerpt: “Clearly, the law imposed on this defendant a duty to maintain his property ‘in a reasonably safe condition in view of all the circumstances, including the likelihood of injury to others, the seriousness of the injury, and the burden of avoiding the risk.’ Mounsey v. Ellard, supra, quoting Smith v. Arbaugh’s Restaurant, Inc., 469 F.2d 97, 100 (D.C. Cir. 1972)… However, the defendant was ‘not obliged to supply a place of maximum safety, but only one which would be safe to a person who exercises such minimum care as the circumstances reasonably indicate.’”}

Jenkins v. Rainear, 371 Mass. 293 (1976).proposition: Defendant’s negligence violated established Massachusetts principles of reasonable care, including those articulated in Mounsey v. Ellard, 363 Mass. 693, 707 (1973), Toubiana v. Priestly, 402 Mass. 84, 88 (1988), and Jenkins v. Rainear, 371 Mass. 293 (1976).
Jenkins v. Rainear, 371 Mass. 293 (1976).case_name: Sydney v. Commissioner of Corporations & Taxation
Jenkins v. Rainear, 371 Mass. 293 (1976).support_reasoning: This opinion is a tax/declaratory-judgment procedure case, dealing with whether the availability of an administrative remedy (appeal to the Appellate Tax Board) bars a declaratory judgment action. It does not address negligence, duty of reasonable care, or the substantive tort principles discussed in Mounsey or Toubiana. Citing Jenkins v. Rainear (this case) as authority for Massachusetts principles of reasonable care is therefore inaccurate and unsupported by the text or holding.
Jenkins v. Rainear, 371 Mass. 293 (1976).relevant_excerpt: "Our decided cases do not accord with the judge’s approach. We have held repeatedly, in the tax field, that a declaratory action is not ousted merely by the fact that the taxpayer has an administrative path to relief. Rather we have taken the view that the judge in such a case may still exercise a discretion as to whether the action should be entertained."

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 6B.proposition: Award interest pursuant to G.L. c. 231, § 6B;
